Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Integration of magnetic and visual cues by C57BL/6 mice in a 4-armed ('plus') water maze
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Studies of mammalian spatial cognition have focused primarily on visual landmarks and self-generated cues (optic flow, vestibular cues, etc.) that operate over relatively short distances, and largely ignored the global reference provided by the earth's magnetic field that can be used to place local arrays of visual landmarks into register to form a map of familiar space. Evidence that the magnetic compass of birds and at least some rodents (i.e., mice and rats) may be mediated by magnetically sensitive photoreceptors in the retina has led to speculation that the magnetic field may be perceived as a complex, 3-dimensional pattern of light intensity or color superimposed on the animal's surroundings. This pattern could function as a simple spherical grid or coordinate system that helps to encode directional and spatial input from other sensory modalities. Behavioral studies have shown that mice have a well-developed magnetic compass, but there is no information for mice or any other mammal on how magnetic and non-magnetic cues interact. The proposed research will use a mouse water maze assay to investigate the relative salience of magnetic and visual landmark cues when both types of cues are present, and to determine whether mice that learn a directional response relative to the magnetic field will transfer the learned relationship to visual landmarks, and vice versa. Broader impacts of this research include: (1) understanding the role of a novel sensory input (magnetic cues) in a behavioral assay widely used in biomedical research (e.g., to study Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia), (2) providing undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds with interdisciplinary research training, and (3) collaborating with a nationally recognized expert on interdisciplinary training and assessment to develop materials to assess undergraduate research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We evaluated the ability of C57 BL/6 mice to transfer a learned directional response from an earth strength magnetic field to a novel landmark array. In baseline ‘magnetic training’ experiments, we’ve shown that mice given two brief training trials while confined to one arm of the water maze can learn the direction of the submerged platform relative to the magnetic field.  In ‘cue transfer’ experiments, mice were trained in the same way to associate the location of the submerged platform with a direction relative to the magnetic field.  Twelve to eighteen hours later, they were given a 5 minute exposure to a novel array of visual landmarks in the presence of the magnetic field from a pedestal positioned just above the water surface in the center of the water maze. The mice tested 5-6 hours later in the presence of the visual landmarks without magnetic cues oriented in the learned direction using only the visual landmarks. Our findings provide preliminary evidence that mice trained in a 4-arm ('plus') water maze to locate a submerged platform in a consistent direction relative to the magnetic field, can transfer the learned relationship to a novel landmark array, and subsequently use the landmark array in the absence of magnetic cues to orient in the trained direction.  Interestingly, however, mice in both baseline 'magnetic training', and in 'cue transfer', experiments showed a consistent ~45° clockwise deviation from the trained direction.  In addition, as occurred in several earlier series of baseline 'magnetic training' experiments (e.g., Fig 1), there was a deterioration or reversal of the directional response after the first ~4 animals in each test group (Fig 2). The 45° rotation of orientation may have been caused by low level radio frequency noise which has been shown to affect magnetic compass responses in other organisms. Because the majority of investigators working on rodent spatial cognition are skeptical that mice have a magnetic sense, let alone can transfer a learned directional response from magnetic to visual landmark cues, we are continuing the 'magnetic training' and 'cue transfer' experiments in an attempt to obtain a more straight-forward response. The contributions of this ongoing research include the development of new methods that can be used by other investigators to screen out anthropogenic radio frequency fields that may interfere with the use of magnetic cues. Findings from this research are helping to bridge the gap between traditional approaches to studying mammalian spatial cognition and those used to study magnetic compass orientation.
